Michigan Initial Health & Safety Training Module B   
Section 2: Administration of Medications

Academic Integrity in the Online Environment

Assessing students in the online environment comes with a lot of questions for both teachers and students alike. Before we take a deeper look into all the ways digital forms of assessment can be beneficial, it’s important to address a common concern: what does academic integrity mean and what do violations of academic integrity look like online?

Select each word below to review and understand how Michigan Virtual defines academic integrity and its violations in an online environment.

Academic Integrity

“All work you submit is created by you and is an original representation of your work. It means that what you submit is your own work.”

Plagiar

“When a student who represents work that has been copied from any published resource such as, but not limited to, Wikipedia, electronic texts, videos, or any source without the proper credit (any resource that is not a student’s own work).” -Common sources include Wikipedia, Chegg, Brainly, Course Hero

  • Student copies a paragraph of text directly from Wikipedia as their own
  • Student searches and finds an entire essay on Course Hero and submits
  • Student finds assignment on Chegg and changes a few words before submitting

-Boleski and Trombetta, Feb. 2022

Emergency meds available outdoors/field trips

If a child has emergency medications ordered they should be readily available when the child is outdoors and always taken when the child is on a field trip. Examples of this would be an asthma inhaler or injectable epinephrine. Keep in mind that all licensed centers and homes are required to have emergency plans which include how children with chronic medical conditions will be accommodated for in all types of emergencies, including administration of medications.

Wash hands before and after administering meds

Always wash your hands before and after administering medications. Washing before prevents contamination of medications. Washing after prevents residual fragments of the medication being transmitted.
